The '''[[2007 NFL season|2007]] [[Miami Dolphins]] season''' was the 38th season for the team in the [[National Football League]] and 42nd season overall<ref>{{cite web | title = Miami Dolphins History | work = NFL-History.com | url = http://www.nfl-history.com/dolphins.php | accessdate = 24 June | accessyear = 2007 }} </ref>. The team finished the 2007 season with the worst record in the NFL, 1-15, thus giving them the first pick in the 2008 NFL draft. They also failed to improve upon a 6-10 season in 2006.<ref>{{cite web | title = Miami Dolphins 2006 Schedule | work = NFL.com | url = http://www.nfl.com/teams/schedule/MIA/2006 | accessdate = 24 June | accessyear = 2007 }} </ref> Under former head coach [[Nick Saban]] in a year that began with high hopes<ref>{{cite web | title = Saban, Dolphins Set Sights on Overtaking Pats | work = WashingtonPost.com | url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/blog/2006/05/26/BL2006052600920.html | accessdate = 24 June | accessyear = 2007 }} </ref>, Saban resigned from the Dolphins to become the head coach at the [[University of Alabama]], after repeatedly saying he would stay with the Dolphins<ref name="SabanLeaves">{{cite web | title = After repeated denials, Saban takes Bama job | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=2718488 | accessdate = 15 June | accessyear = 2007 }} </ref>. The Dolphins entered 2007 in the process of rebuilding under new head coach Cam Cameron, the former [[offensive coordinator]] for the [[San Diego Chargers]]. The coaching staff has already undergone significant changes, with approximately twelve coaches newly hired or re-assigned. Cameron has also made various changes to the team's roster, with a more than a dozen players being added or re-signed and just as many being released, traded or allowed to sign elsewhere. The Dolphins won their first (and only) game of the 2007 NFL season against the [[Baltimore Ravens]] in overtime on December 16. Six of the team's losses in 2007 were by margins of three points or less.
The '''[[2007 NFL season|2007]] [[Miami Dolphins]] season''' was the 38th season for the team in the [[National Football League]] and 42nd season overall<ref>{{cite web | title = Miami Dolphins History | work = NFL-History.com | url = http://www.nfl-history.com/dolphins.php | accessdate = 24 June | accessyear = 2007 }} </ref>. The team finished the 2007 season with the worst record in the NFL, 1-15, thus giving them the first pick in the 2008 NFL draft. They also failed to improve upon a 6-10 season in 2006.<ref>{{cite web | title = Miami Dolphins 2006 Schedule | work = NFL.com | url = http://www.nfl.com/teams/schedule/MIA/2006 | accessdate = 24 June | accessyear = 2007 }} </ref> Under former head coach [[Nick Saban]] in a year that began with high hopes<ref>{{cite web | title = Saban, Dolphins Set Sights on Overtaking Pats | work = WashingtonPost.com | url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/blog/2006/05/26/BL2006052600920.html | accessdate = 24 June | accessyear = 2007 }} </ref>, Saban resigned from the Dolphins to become the head coach at the [[University of Alabama]], after repeatedly saying he would stay with the Dolphins<ref name="SabanLeaves">{{cite web | title = After repeated denials, Saban takes Bama job | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=2718488 | accessdate = 15 June | accessyear = 2007 }} </ref>. The Dolphins entered 2007 in the process of rebuilding under new head coach Cam Cameron, the former [[offensive coordinator]] for the [[San Diego Chargers]]. The coaching staff has already undergone significant changes, with approximately twelve coaches newly hired or re-assigned. Cameron has also made various changes to the team's roster, with a more than a dozen players being added or re-signed and just as many being released, traded or allowed to sign elsewhere. The Dolphins won their first (and only) game of the 2007 NFL season against the [[Baltimore Ravens]] in overtime on December 16. Six of the team's losses in 2007 were by margins of three points or less.
